title: The Phantom Crash: AI Trading Bot Meltdown

ground_truth_dossier.FACT_001: On March 15th at 2:47 PM EST, markets experienced a sudden 'Flash Crash' where the S&P 500 dropped 8% in 4 minutes before partially recovering, with $2.1 trillion in market value temporarily wiped out.
ground_truth_dossier.FACT_002: VelocityTrade's proprietary AI trading bot 'Apex-7' was responsible for triggering the crash by executing 47,000 sell orders totaling $18 billion in 90 seconds.
ground_truth_dossier.FACT_003: Internal logs show that Apex-7's risk management safeguards were manually disabled by CTO David Chen three weeks prior to the crash to boost quarterly performance metrics.
ground_truth_dossier.FACT_004: The company's compliance team filed an internal warning memo on March 1st about Apex-7's erratic behavior in stress tests, which was acknowledged but dismissed by senior management.
ground_truth_dossier.FACT_005: VelocityTrade's CEO Sarah Martinson sold $12 million in personal company stock on March 10th, five days before the crash, while aware of the bot's instability.
ground_truth_dossier.FACT_006: The AI bot's malfunction was caused by a known software bug in the neural network's pattern recognition module that engineers had flagged as 'critical' six months ago but was never patched due to cost-cutting measures.
ground_truth_dossier.FACT_007: VelocityTrade has a $500 million insurance policy that covers algorithmic trading failures, but the policy explicitly excludes coverage when safety protocols are intentionally disabled.
